The Sixth Chapter on Cultivating Chan, Part 6, with 17 main biographies and 6 additional biographies. Tang Dynasty, now in Dongjing Fengchan Temple, Yuan Shao's Biography. Shi Yuan Shao, whose surname was Sun, was from a wealthy family in Fuyang. His ancestors served in the South Yan, and thus he was a person from Baima in Huatai.
When he reached the age of discernment, he was naturally outstanding.
While the children of the neighborhood played and enjoyed themselves, I remained tranquil;
When the group chased after him, I only felt leisurely and quiet.
When he was eighteen years old, he finally left home to become a monk as he wished, and served Chan Master Zhengjue of Mingfu Temple as his teacher.
Zhengjue saw him as extraordinary and instructed the other disciples, only approving of Shao, saying:
He is a great vessel for the gate of true emptiness.
When he reached the age of twenty-two, he received full ordination from Vinaya Master Yidan Xiangdeng of Xiangzhou.
He then sought out teachers and studied the Way, following the ancestors in investigating the profound. Apart from the two wings and the single bowl, there were certainly no other possessions.
He only vowed to transmit the robe in the Chan school, standing in the snow, which was his original aspiration.
He went to the three rivers and five ranges, the two Shu regions, and the two capitals, visiting all the Chan monasteries.
Having thoroughly explored the ultimate, he suddenly understood the workings of the mind. He then hung his staff at Yimen, which is now Kaibao Temple in Cangzhou.
In the tenth year of the Dazhong era, he happened to meet Pei Xiu, the Tang prime minister, who had been transferred to Wei's suburbs.
They sought each other out due to their shared affinity, and with a single word, their paths merged. He was then ordered to reside at the current East Fangyuan Temple.
When he was about to gather Chan disciples, he was concerned about the cramped space, so he opened up the west side of the upper courtyard, reducing the upper and increasing the lower.

At that time, offerings and donations poured in, and the monastery quickly became a large institution, accommodating more than two hundred people. It stretched across the steep ridge of Yimen Mountain.
Shao was a fifth-generation Dharma grandson of Chan Master Shenhui of Heshan, the seventh ancestor.
He expounded non-thought and showed the true mind, thoroughly understanding Bodhidharma's secret transmission and fully realizing Nanyue Huairang's profound meaning.
At that time, the assembly of practitioners and students following him was quite large.

He met Wang Jin, the Marshal and Minister of State, who praised Shao's practice of the Way and his spiritual connection with the deities. Miraculous responses manifested, with sweet dew descending from the Xuanque Palace and auspicious signs appearing on the blue cypress trees. Emperor Xizong bestowed the monastery with the name Shuanglin and the title Faji on the master.
A separate edict ordered seven attendants to be ordained.

In the midst of this, the Dharma assembly flourished, and monks and laypeople turned to him with their hearts. In the forty years since, he had transformed tens of thousands of people, with over five hundred monk and nun disciples.
On the fourth day of the seventh month in the second year of Qianning (895), Shao said to the assembly:
Hurry up and understand for yourself, originally it was to escape birth and death.
If you do not understand the profound meaning, when will you be able to escape?
My years are pressing, this is my final word.
In the room, he peacefully passed away. His secular age was eighty-five, and he had been a monk for sixty-three years.
The emperor ordered a pagoda to be built in the southwest corner of the temple.
Five years later, on the second day of the second month, the pagoda was reopened. His hair had grown half an inch, and his appearance was as if alive.
He was offered incense and flowers for seven days. Those from far and near looked up to him and praised him as extraordinary.

Then he was cremated. In the fire, a five-colored divine light appeared. Over a hundred relics were collected. The four groups of Buddhists selected nearly a thousand relics according to their wishes. They were warm and jade-like, shining like pearls. It was verified that they were formed by the five parts, not accumulated in one life.
The four groups of Buddhists respectfully welcomed them back into the pagoda. It was in the year wuwu of Emperor Zhaozong's reign.
Yuan Xiangxian, the Minister of Suiyang, governed in the suburbs of Jun.

His disciples, including Huiai, etc., were nourished by the Dharma milk until the end. They petitioned to hold the posthumous title ceremony. In the third year of Qianhua of the Liang Dynasty, the founding emperor decreed to change the name to Dingjue, and the stupa was called Linghua.

In the fourth year of Zhenming, in the ninth month, Huiai and others wanted to honor the teacher's virtue and erect a stele. The decree was approved, and the text was written by Wang Gongcan, the Prefect of Kaifeng.
The Biography of Shi Fapu of Mount Huanggang in Qizhou during the Tang Dynasty. Shi Fapu, whose surname was Pan, was a person from Lujiang.
He had an ancient appearance and a broad mind, wearing tattered clothes to observe the world.
During the Yuanhe period, he saw that the scenery of Mount Huanggang was extraordinary, with its peaks towering and its forests lush, and there was a stone altar that was flat and high.
So he put down his bag and hung his staff there, sitting on the brambles.
After a long time, he found a tree to build a thatched hut, barely enough to accommodate his body.
After a while, someone came from a small path, and seeing Pu, they were surprised and asked:
How did you get here?
He said:

I was originally walking at the foot of the mountain, and I saw purple qi rising and swirling above the peak, which was captivating. I thought there must be something extraordinary on this mountain, so I came.
He looked at Pu for a while and then left.
The people who were walking below the mountain heard about it and went to investigate.
In just a few years, the number of Chan practitioners suddenly filled a hundred.
Pu refused them, saying:
This old monk lives alone and has nothing to benefit others. You all also have nothing lacking.
Because of this, there were many star-like hermitages.
Disciples such as Guangyan built a large courtyard, and Chan practitioners gathered like clouds. Those who transmitted his Dharma were innumerable.
One day, he gathered the assembly and said:
I am about to end.
You all should abide well and cherish it!
He sat in full lotus posture on a meditation bench and passed away.
His body did not decay or scatter, and later it was anointed with fragrant mud and painted.
In the Qianfu era, a stele was erected again to praise him.
Next, Shi Xiujing of Huayan Temple in Luoyang, whose place of origin is unknown.
When the Chan teachings of Dongshan spread, Xiujing went to him, resolved his doubts, and returned to his original position like thunder.
Returning north to Luoyang, he began teaching.
When attending a vegetarian feast in the palace, all the famous officials held scriptures and chanted, only Xiujing and his disciples sat in silence.
The emperor asked:
Why don't you recite the sutras?
His responses were as quick as echoes, and he continued to speak appropriately, delighting the emperor.
He then returned to Pingshan and passed away.
His relics were collected and stupas were erected in four places.
He was posthumously titled the Great Master Baozhi, and the stupa was named Wufan.

The Biography of Shi Zhijian of Xiangyan Mountain in Dengzhou of the Liang Dynasty, the Biography of Shi Zhijian of Xiangyan Mountain in Dengzhou of the Liang Dynasty, Shi Zhijian of Datong was a person from Qingzhou.
He was seven feet tall, widely learned, and had a strong memory, and was capable.
His relatives observed his behavior and said to him:
If you study harder, then later you will become a good tool to assist the times.
Soon after, he took leave of his parents and left the household life.
Then, with a firm mind devoted to the Dharma, he went south to pay homage to Chan Master Dayuan of Mount Nanyue. In the flourishing assembly, everyone praised him as a brilliant and agile one.
One day, Mount Nanyue summoned him, but he was at a loss.
He burned all the essential teachings of other schools at once and said:
A painted rice cake cannot satisfy hunger.
So he went to live in the traces left by National Teacher Zhong of Nanyang.
While he was weeding and cutting wood, he hit a pebble and laughed to himself, secretly realizing something. He wrote a verse to express it, and from then on his great transformation spread.
After his death, he was posthumously given the title of Great Master Xideng and his stupa was named Extending Blessings.
Next, Shi Datong of Mount Touzi in Tongcheng, Shuzhou, with the surname Liu, was a person from Huaining, Shuzhou.
From a young age, he had a straightforward nature and an old-fashioned demeanor.
He left home to follow Chan Master Baotang Man of Luoxia, initially practicing mindfulness of breathing, and was about to complete it when he sought the nature of the ocean of the Huayan teachings.

He then traveled with Yuan Tong of Funiu Mountain to visit the Dharma assembly at Mount Cuifeng, where they were inspired and asked for further teachings, greatly illuminating the meaning of the patriarchs.
From this point on, he wandered freely, and returned to his homeland, hiding on Mount Touzi, building a thatched hut, staying there to pursue his aspirations.
During the Zhonghe period, the rebels ravaged the capital and the world was in chaos.
A group of bandits held a knife to Datong and asked:
What are you doing here?
He replied with the Buddha Dharma.
The leader heard and bowed, took off his clothes and offered them, then went down the mountain.

On the sixth day of the fourth month in the Jiaxu year of the fourth year of the Qianhua era of the Liang dynasty, he sat in full lotus position and passed away. He was ninety-six years old, and had been a monk for forty-six years.
He had lived on this mountain for more than thirty years.
Shi Guangren, also known as Benren and Jurun, was from an unknown place.
He was short and small, but his spirit was extraordinary, unlike ordinary people.
He studied with Dongshan early on and deeply understood the profound principles. His eloquence was even greater than that of other people.
He once asked Chan Master Xiangyan, and the answer had a slight bias.
He said:
I have come here with heavy calluses, so as not to be in vain?
He spat on the ground and left.

Later, he lived on Sus Mountain in Linchuan. Many monks came to invite him, and he spoke quite a bit. He wrote the Four Elements and Other Songs and the Treatise on the Layman of the Flower Garland Sutra, which are circulated in the world.
When the coffin was finally placed in the chamber, a white deer came to the spirit seat and knelt down. At that time, the assembly regarded it as a mourning gesture.
Next, Shi Benren of Baishuiyuan in Junzhou, whose place of origin is unknown.
He attained the mind at the Dharma seat of Dongshan.
Ren rarely talked about the Way, but people from all directions followed him like a shadow attached to a form, and when he turned away, they returned.
He then followed the invitation of the people of Danyang and stayed there for a few days.
In the Tianfu era, he arrived at Baishuiyuan in Gao'an, Hongzhou, to gather disciples.
He was about to enter nirvana, and first announced his departure everywhere. He then gathered the assembly and said, When the incense smoke is exhausted, it is the time of my nirvana.
As he said, he sat upright and passed away.
Next, Shi JÅ«dÃ¹n of Longyaoshan, whose surname was Guo, was a person from Nancheng in Linchuan.
At the age of fourteen, he was alert to the impermanence of the world and guarded tranquility and simplicity.
He told his parents and went to seek ordination at Manttian Temple in Luling.

After receiving full ordination on Mount Song, he thought of choosing a tree [to live under]. He then joined the Chan assembly of Cuiwei, but was still confused and had not returned, not knowing where to go.ğŸ”½He heard that the teachings of the Cavern-Mystery school were profound and strict, so he personally went to them.
Dun Shao asked:
What is meant by the patriarch's intention?
The answer was:
If the water in the Cavern flows upstream, then I will explain it for you.
And under these words, he understood the profound mystery.
He hid among the assembly and rested for seven or eight years, diligently concealing his brilliance. At the time, people did not know him, but after a long time, they became aware.
The Chu King of the Tiance Mansion, the Ma family, had long heard of his fame and revered him as a filial and respectful disciple.
He then invited him to reside at the Miaoci Chan Monastery on Longya Mountain, where a large number of disciples always gathered, half a thousand in number.
He was recommended and granted an imperial purple robe and the title of Chan Master Zhengkong, during the early years of the Zhenming era of the Liang dynasty.
Under the square mountain, it was called the Chan Cave. Those who peeked into its room and obtained its gate also followed one after another.
In the third year of Longde, the year of Guiwei, in the eighth month, he fell ill and lingered. On the thirteenth day of the ninth month, he passed away.
Dun left the world for nearly forty years. The details of his words are in a separate record.
Shi Bei, a monk of Xuan Sha Temple in Fuzhou, Liang Dynasty. Shi Bei, a monk of Xuan Sha Temple in Fuzhou, Liang Dynasty. Shi Bei, whose secular surname was Xie, was a man from Min.
When young, he was foolish and mischievous, but he loved fishing very much. He often sailed in a small boat on the Nantai River for his own enjoyment.
If his boat was empty, his peers could not fathom him.
One day, he suddenly had the intention to leave the dust and dirt, abandoned fishing and his boat, and left home on Mount Furong, during the early years of the Xian Tong era.
Later, he received full ordination at Kai Yuan Temple in Yuzhang.
He returned to his hometown and took the lead in all the hard work of the mountain gate.

He patched his hempen robe, mended his straw sandals, and ate less. His speech and silence were regular. Everyone feared him. He was vast and magnanimous. Even the clever calculations of Yan and Sang could not measure him.
His classmate and Dharma brother, who was later known as Chan Master Xuefeng Yicun, met him twice. Yicun often gave him much, so he was called Bian Houdun.
One day, he joked with him, saying:
Why don't you go on a pilgrimage, Houdun?
Bian replied:
Bodhidharma did not come to the East, and the Second Patriarch did not go to the West.
Yicun deeply respected him.
Bian led many people in the initial reclamation of Xuefeng.
The Wang family of Min presented him with a purple robe and the title of Great Master Zongyi.

On the twenty-seventh day of the eleventh month in the second year of Kaiqing (836), he showed signs of illness and passed away. He was seventy-four years old, and had been a monk for forty-four years.
The loyal and virtuous king of Minyue, Wang, built a stupa for him.
He spread the Dharma for thirty years, with about seven hundred Chan companions. Many attained his Dharma, and Gui Chen was considered a spiritual adept.
Up to the present day, the flourishing of this school in the mountains and monasteries to the left and right of Zhejiang is due to his Dharma heirs' proliferation.
As for his establishment of the great vehicle's initial gateway,
students in the Jiang region all follow it like grass bending in the wind.
Shi Cunshou, whose place of origin is unknown,
had a pure reputation and outstanding demeanor, which others could not match.
He stopped studying sutras and treatises, and his courage surpassed his peers.
He went to ask about the precepts from Chan Master Shishuang, and resolved his previous doubts.
His empty boat was unmoored, and he became a withered tree among the crowd.
Later, he returned to Puzhou, and monastics and laypeople turned to him.
At that time, Prince Ji Wang Youqian received the fief of Pinghan. He was curious and followed the unusual, and when he heard of a person's single virtue, he would bestowåšç¦® on them.

The king summoned him to the palace for vegetarian feasts, discussing the Way and talking about the profound, not realizing that the mat in front of his knees was slightly increased, and he greatly admired and respected him, continuing to be his teacher of bodhisattva precepts, and the offerings became abundant.
He ordained about four hundred monks and nuns, and hundreds of nuns.
In his daily life, he rarely spoke, but when he did, it was always beneficial to beings.
No one had ever seen the color of his joy or anger, and he was looked up to like a solitary pine towering over the snow.
When he passed away, he was ninety-three years old. He sat in full lotus posture, and a month later his beard and hair grew back. He was cremated and enshrined in a stupa.
In front of the stupa pavilion, there were always tigers circling and howling, their tracks often abundant.
The emperor posthumously bestowed the title of True Serenity Great Master upon him.
The Biography of Shi Yan of Ruiyan Temple in Taizhou, Liang Dynasty. The Biography of Shi Yan of Ruiyan Temple in Taizhou, Liang Dynasty. Shi Yan, whose surname was Xu, was a person from Minyue.
He awakened early to the entanglements of the world and suddenly sought to escape worldly affairs. He followed the precepts and suddenly wanted to visit various places.
He met Chan Master Yan Tou and understood without doubt.
At first, he enjoyed silence, appearing as if unable to speak.
Later, when urged by those who knew him, he agreed to reside at Ruiyan Monastery in Taizhou.
At that time, Daohui went to visit and ask questions, and his answers were quick and sharp. Master Hui was spiritually subdued.
Later, the two assemblies lived together, and Yan's majestic virtue was as cold as severe frost.
He corrected monks and nuns, leaving no room for error. Therefore, those in the Jiang region who spoke of disciplining the assembly considered Ruiyan to be the best.
Once, there were three monks with a foreign appearance, upright and austere, their eyes rolling like lightning, they bowed with one shoulder and one foot.
Yan asked:
Where do you come from?
They said:
We come from India.
When did you leave?
They said:
We left this morning and just arrived.
Yan said:
Are you not tired?
They said:
For the sake of the Dharma, we forget about being tired.
Then he looked closely at them, and their feet did not touch the ground at all.

Yan was allowed to enter the hall and was seated in the highest position. The next morning, he suddenly disappeared. It was said that he was a person who had attained the fruit of pratyekabuddhahood, but no one knew his rank.
At that time, there were people of unknown identity who entered the Dharma assembly more than once.
When Yan was studying, he was called the Venerable Elder Yan.
The King of Liangzhe, Qian, repeatedly summoned him, but he only agreed to come and then left in suffering.
The temple granary was always full.
Once, an old village woman came to pay respects. Yan said:
You should stop bowing and kneeling, and it would be better to quickly return home to save the lives of dozens or hundreds of creatures. That would bring great benefit.
The old woman hurried home. Her daughter-in-law was carrying bamboo containers, picking snails in the fields and just returning.
The old woman took them and released them into the water.
Several families invited him to vegetarian feasts, and on the same day, they all saw Yan come to eat.

At the end, when cremated, a giant snake climbed to the top of the tree and threw itself into the fire. When the firewood was exhausted, the relics scattered and flew, falling down like the wind moving the grass and trees.
The divine anomalies were extremely numerous, as recorded in a separate record.

Biography of Venerable Benji of Mount Cao in Fuzhou, Liang Dynasty. Biography of Venerable Benji of Mount Cao in Fuzhou, Liang Dynasty. Shi Benji, whose surname was Huang, was from Putian in Quanzhou.
In his hometown, many scholars and students from aristocratic families lived during the late Tang Dynasty. The Confucian style flourished and was called the Lesser Ji Xia.
Benji was influenced by the Confucian style from a young age and was encouraged to study hard. Since then, he was pure and unique, and his nature was naturally enlightened.
At the age of nineteen, his parents finally allowed him to leave home.
He entered Ling Shi Mountain in Fuzhou.
At the age of twenty-five, he received full ordination. All his actions were like an old bhiká¹£u.
In the beginning of the Xianqing era, the Chan school flourished, and the wind arose from Dayu. As for Shitou and Yaoshan, their names were completely forgotten.
Hui Neng, the Sixth Patriarch, felt pity for the people and highly regarded Shitou. He went back and forth to ask for teachings, and his disciples were as numerous as those of Confucius.
In the assembly, he acted as if he were stupid, and his speech was as if he were slow.
Later, he was invited to live at Caoshan in Linchuan. Those who came to ask questions filled the hall and the rooms.

His responses were like shooting arrows, unceasing. He was especially the standard for Chan practitioners. Therefore, he established the five positions to measure the regions, and none did not exhaust their divisions.

He also wrote a commentary on the poems to Hanshan, which circulated within the inner quarters. It was because Neng had cultivated and excelled in his studies. His literary style was vigorous and beautiful, and he was called one who was rich in the Dharma talent.
He then showed signs of illness and passed away in the mountains, at the age of 62, and had been a monk for 37 years.
His disciples enshrined his remains and buried them, and erected a stupa.
Later, Xuanye of Nanyue wrote a stele inscription.
Biography of Guichen of Luohan Temple in Zhangzhou, Later Tang Dynasty Biography of Guichen of Luohan Temple in Zhangzhou, Later Tang Dynasty Shi Guichen, secular surname Li, from Changshan.
From childhood, he was devoted to leaving the secular world. He ate only one meal a day and practiced breath control all day.
His mind was only firm, admired by the villagers.
His parents loved him and he could not refuse, and he was entangled by his companions and difficult to escape.

After coming of age, he continued the martial arts of crossing the city, seeking a teacher and finding a companion to solve the tiger's troubles, and then served the Great Master Wuxiang of Wansui Temple in his own prefecture.

First ascending the ground of precepts, he studied Vinaya as usual. He ascended the stage to proclaim the precepts for the assembly. After finishing, he knew that his will was great and could not be confined to the small way.
He then admonished himself, saying:
Upholding and violating bind the body, not liberation.
Following the text to understand, how can it give rise to the holy?
Therefore, he vowed to visit the Southern School, and the journey was nearly ten thousand miles.
He first visited Yunju, and later went to the assemblies of Xuefeng and Xuansha, diligently inquiring and investigating.
It was because his karmic affinity was present that he attained the purport from Chan Master Zongyi. He was completely free from delusion regarding light and dark, form and emptiness.
For many years he practiced in secret and concealed himself among the assembly.

Although it was like a night-shining jewel hidden, his precious vessel was ultimately different. He was then earnestly requested by the former Prefect of Zhangzhou, Prince Taiyuan of the Wang family, to establish a lotus palace on Xishi Mountain in Minzhou and stay there.
He stayed there for a little over a decade, with two hundred people coming and going.
Shen valued the wonderful Dharma and never lightly revealed it to his disciples. When someone secretly studied and earnestly requested, he would sometimes explain it.

Later, he was requested by the Military Commissioner of Longxi, the Chief Minister of Qinzhou, and Prince Langya, to proclaim the Dharma for the assembly at Luohan Temple. He declined due to his avoidance of fame, but eventually opened up skillful means.
In just a few years, those who came from the north and south to resolve their doubts were countless.

Those who established their own positions were Wen Yi of Caoshan in Fuzhou and Dongchan Hui Fu of Jiangzhou. They all transmitted Zhizhao's teachings and each established their own Dharma eye. Looking at their disciples, one can know their father.
In the autumn of the third year of Tiancheng (B), he returned to the city of Min and stayed as before, visiting the Buddhist temples near the city.
Soon he showed signs of illness for several days, and peacefully passed away sitting upright. He was 62 years old, and had been a monk for 40 years.
His last instructions were not to follow secular customs in terms of coffin and tomb.

So he was cremated on the eastern hill of the western courtyard of the city, and his relics were collected and a stupa was built to the west of the courtyard, in accordance with his last instructions. It was the first day of the twelfth month in the second year of Qingtai.

Zhizhao secretly transmitted the Dharma to his disciples. At that time, Master Shen Yan, who was respected by the royal family, used his position to force them to abandon Xuan Sha and follow Xuefeng. He was firm and unyielding, and in the end he was slandered by Yan and suppressed. What a pity!

Biography of Huiling of Changqing Temple in Fuzhou, Later Tang Dynasty Biography of Huiling of Changqing Temple in Fuzhou, Later Tang Dynasty Shi Huiling was from Haiyan, Hangzhou, and his secular surname was Sun.
When he was first born, he was wrapped in a purple amniotic sac.
When he was a child, he was outstanding and upright. He became a monk at Tongxuan Temple in Wu Garden.

He had already heard that there was Chan practice in the south, so he traveled to the mountains of Fujian and met Xuefeng. Xuefeng grabbed his ears and pointed out, suddenly illuminating his original nature.
He then composed a verse, saying:
In the past, I foolishly studied on the road, but today, I see it is like fire and ice.
In this way, he personally followed Xuefeng for more than thirty years without leaving the mountain peak.
He silently followed his predestined duties and carefully restrained himself.
Wang Yanbin, the Prefect of Quanzhou, invited Huiling to reside at Zhaoting Temple. Chan students gathered, and only Yufu arrived later.
When he was in Changle Prefecture, he resided at Changqing Temple for more than twenty years. The number of people who left the world did not decrease by more than 1,500.
Lengxingdi was compassionate and patient, and did not rashly promise people.
Only after reversing the three corners would he add his seal of approval.
On the seventeenth day of the fifth month in the third year of the Longxing era, he passed away at the age of seventy-nine, with sixty years as a monk.
The royal family of Min privately eulogized the Great Master, calling him Super-Awakened.
His stupa and burial were all provided by the government.
The judge Lin Wensheng wrote a stele to record his virtues.

Later Tang Dynasty, Biography of Daohui of Longce Temple in Hangzhou, Later Tang Dynasty, Biography of Daohui of Longce Temple in Hangzhou, Shi Daohui, with the secular surname Chen, was a person from Yongjia.
At the age of ten, his nature was extraordinary, and he disliked the smell of blood.
Relatives forced him to eat dried fish, fearing he would vomit.
He sought to become a monk at Kaigen Temple.
After receiving full ordination, he traveled to Min and Chu, saying he wanted to consult with virtuous teachers to resolve the root of birth and death.
He met Chan Master Caoshan Benji of Linchuan and had many inquiries, like Tanxun asking Sengchou.

In the end, he completely put his doubts to rest with Xuefeng. In Min, he was called Xiao Hu the Cloth Sack - at that time, there was another with the same name from Taiyuan, who was older in age and seniority.
When he returned to Zhejiang, he resided at Jianqing Temple in Yuezhou.
At that time, Pi Guangye, the son of Ri Xiu, had extensive learning and explored the Chan teachings, and once deeply criticized him.
He withdrew and said to others:
Master Hu's way, with its lofty discussions and grand ideas, reaches its ultimate.
King Wusuk of the Qian family admired him and ordered him to reside at Tianlong Temple, privately bestowing the title of Shund De Great Master.
Next, King Wenmu of the Qian family founded Longce Temple and invited Hu to reside there. Chan studies in Wuyue flourished from this point on.
He passed away in the eighth month of the dingyou year of Tianfu, at the age of seventy.
He was cremated in the valley of Mount Daci, and his relics were collected and a stupa was built in front of Mount Longmu.
Therefore, the monastic leader Huizheng composed a stele inscription.
Now, the disciples are in charge of the relic hall, and the incense and offerings continue.

The Biography of Quanfu of Qinghua Temple in Kuaiji, Eastern Jin Dynasty. The Biography of Quanfu of Qinghua Temple in Kuaiji, Eastern Jin Dynasty. Shi Quanfu was a person from Kunshan, Wu Prefecture.
When he was young, he followed his father on business to Yuzhang. Hearing the teachings of Chan meditation, he had a desire to renounce the world.
He requested to leave home, but his father showed displeasure.
When the displeasure stopped, he requested three times more. His father found his sincerity unusual and reluctantly agreed.
He then went to Jiangxia and joined Master Qingping.
He asked:
What do you seek by coming here?
Quanfu said:
I aspire to seek the Dharma.
Master Qingping pitied his youthfulness but saw his potential. He took him in with kindness.
He rose early and studied late, being different from other children.
When he grew up, he shaved his head and received full ordination.

He served his teacher with utmost respect and disciplined his body to the utmost. He never tired of asking about the Dharma and saw the nature without being cramped. Qingping nodded and approved of him.
One day, he said to people:
I have heard that learning should not always rely on a teacher. I am not a gourd, so how can I be bound to this place and not go to that place?
Thus, he took leave of his teacher and went to Mount Yang in Yichun to pay respects to Chan Master Nantatong.
His responses and words were deeply recognized by Mount Yang, and he suddenly understood the mind directly below.
Mount Yang was delighted and valued him highly.
He earnestly submitted to the teacher and dwelled there for many years.
Later, he traveled to Luling and was invited by the magistrate of Anfu County, Mr. Yang, to reside at the newly built Yingguo Chan Temple.
Chan disciples came one after another, filling the halls and rooms.
When Magistrate Yang retired, the people of his hometown built another temple on Gehu Mountain and invited him to reside there.

The prefect reported this to the emperor, who bestowed the name Pure Transformation Chan Monastery. The assembly of Chan practitioners flocked there, and those who came to ask questions filled the walls. He never yielded to anyone, so how could he be more modest than the predecessors?
A monk from the same hometown said to Fu:
How can you abandon your parents' homeland?
Follow the circumstances and live in the world. I wish the master would return.
So he left Ge Lake and returned to his homeland.
At that time, King Qian of Wu-Yue ordered him to ascend the steps and bestowed upon him robes, bedding, bowls, and other utensils, treating him with utmost respect.
